string-array.name: statue_1_facts
string-array.item: The Bather is on display in the Victoria and Albert Museum, on loan from the Tate Gallery
Toft described his work as \'Idealist\'
From 1885 onwards Toft exhibited at the Royal Academy
In 1891 Toft was elected to the Art Workers Guild and in 1938 he was elected a fellow to the Royal Society of British Sculptors
Albert Toft trained in Wedgwood\'s pottery and in 1881 won a scholarship to study sculpture at the South Kensington Schools
Albert Toft was born in Birmingham 3 June 1862 and died 18 December 1949 in Worthing, Sussex

string-array.name: statue_2_facts
string-array.item: Moai are monolithic human figures carved by the Rapa Nui people
Nearly half are still at Rano Raraku the main moai quarry,hundreds were set on stone platforms called ahu around the island\'s perimeter
The moai are chiefly the living faces (aringa ora) of deified ancestors (aringa ora ata tepuna).
The tallest moai erected, called Paro, was almost 10 metres high and weighed 82 tons
The heaviest weighed 86 tons; one unfinished Moai if complete would have been approximately 21 metres tall with a weight of about 270 tons.
Almost all moai have overly large heads three-eighths the size of the whole statue.

string-array.name: statue_3_facts
string-array.item: The first cast sculpture can be found in front of Grawemeyer Hall on the University of Louisville Belknap Campus in Louisville, Kentucky.
Rodin made the first small plaster version around 1880.
There are about 28 full size castings
The figure was designed to be seen from below, and is normally displayed on a fairly high plinth
Originally named The Poet
The first large-scale bronze casting was finished in 1902 but not presented to the public until 1904.

string-array.name: statue_4_facts
string-array.item: The Dacre Beasts were repainted in 1849 after the fire at Naworth in 1844.
The Dolphin is one of four figures,the others are a Red Bull (Yes really),A ram and A Griffin
Commissioned by Lord Dacre sometime between 1507–1525. Made in Cumbria, England
made by unnamed local craftsmen from a single, large oak grown on the estate
The banner bears the medieval arms of the Greystoke family
Unique survivors of free standing, large-scale wooden heraldic sculpture from the English Renaissance

string-array.name: statue_5_facts
string-array.item: Henry Moore\'s forms are usually abstractions of the human figure, typically depicting mother-and-child or reclining figures
Henry Moore was born 30th July 1898 in Castleford, Yorkshire, died 31st August 1986 Much Hadham Hertfordshire
In 1924 Moore won a six-month scholarship in Northern Italy studying great works of Michelangelo, Giotto di Bondone, and other Old Masters.
Moore was born in Castleford, the son of a coal miner. 7th of 8 children
a plaster cast of a Toltec-Maya sculptural form was to have a profound effect upon Moore\'s work, becoming the primary motif of his sculpture
In 1948 moore won the International Sculpture Prize at the Venice Biennale and was one of the featured artists of the Festival of Britain in 1951.

string-array.name: statue_6_facts
string-array.item: Mentuemhat (c. 700 BC - c. 650 BC) was a Theban official. He is depicted in many statues and buried in tomb TT34 of the Theban Necropolis.
Mentuemhat was the son of Esptah, a Prophet of Amun and Mayor of the City, and Esenkhebi
Mentuemhat served during the reigns of Taharqa and Psamtik I.
Mentuemhat had 3 wives, Wadjerenes,Eskhons,Shepetenmut
Mentuemhat witnessed the rise and fall of the Nubian Dynasty and the Assyrian invasion of Egypt.
He was the fourth prophet of Amun at Thebes, called "the Prince of the City,"serving Taharqa,Tanutamun,Necho I, and Psammetichus I
